newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Colombian presidential candidate targets impunity.
newsitem.headline: Colombian presidential candidate targets impunity.

text.p: Former Interior Minister Horacio Serpa, who has resigned to run for president, on Wednesday described Colombia as a lawless land where virtually all crimes go unpunished.
Serpa, a former judge, told a news conference that Colombia -- which has Latin America's highest kidnapping and murder rates -- had grave problems with its judicial system.
If elected, he said, his administration would put a premimum on "very important judicial activity" aimed at ending "the terrible rate of impunity in Colombia."
Serpa did not elaborate on his promise of a crackdown on crime. But he said "99.5 percent" of all the crimes currently committed in Colombia went unpunished. "That's shameful and it's sad," he said.
Police say they lack the resources and manpower to impose law-and-order on a country of nearly 40 million people torn by leftist guerrillas and criminal drug gangs.
Last year, authorities registered 26,642 murders, or an average of 73 per day. Colombia's military-run police force was just 92,000 strong, including cadets and civilian personnel.
